author: Syed Muthahar Saqaf
text:
Four container lorries transporting coins of different denominations to the tune of Rs. 2.52 crores were detained for a few hours by the flying squad officials here on Sunday for want of proper documents and police escort party.

The flying squad personnel comprising revenue and police officials were conducting surprise check of vehicles near the toll plaza on the Karur – Namakkal national highway at Keerambur before the break of dawn on Sunday, when they spotted four container lorries transporting coins.

The containers possessed coins of Rs. 10, Rs. 5, Rs. 2 and Rs.1 denomination, being transported by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) from Hyderabad to Tiruvananthapuram.

Official sources said that though the drivers of the vehicles possessed documents provided by the RBI, some details, such as the names of the drivers, were missing.

Moreover, the mandatory police escort was also absent.

Following this, all the four container lorries were taken to the office of the Revenue Divisional Officer in the town.

M. Kannan, RDO, verified the available documents and made enquiries with the drivers.

Later, he contacted the RBI office at Hyderabad to clarify certain facts.

Following this, the RBI top officials forwarded all the needed details and documents to substantiate the same by e-mail.

After the receipt of the e-mail, the container lorries were allowed to continue their journey.

Official sources told The Hindu that the lorries were taken to the RDO office as a security measure, as transporting the coins of such a huge volume during the night hours without escort was a risky job.

“The container lorries were released as soon as the e-mail message was received within a few hours”, the sources added.
title: Lorries transporting coins detained by flying squad
